etymologies: mid 16th century: French (earlier form of alcool), or from medieval Latin, from Arabic al-kuḥl ‘the kohl’. In early use the term referred to powders, specifically kohl, and especially those obtained by sublimation; later ‘a distilled or rectified spirit’ (mid 17th century)

definitions: a colorless volatile flammable liquid that is produced by the natural fermentation of sugars and is the intoxicating constituent of wine, beer, spirits, and other drinks, and is also used as an industrial solvent and as fuel

examples.text: alcohol breaks down in the body
the use of gasoline containing alcohol

notes.text: Alternative names: ethanol, ethyl alcohol; chemical formula: C₂H₅OH

shortDefinitions: colourless volatile flammable liquid which is intoxicating constituent of drinks

examples.text: she hasn't drunk alcohol in five years

definitions: any organic compound whose molecule contains one or more hydroxyl groups attached to a carbon atom

examples.text: unpleasant stuff like formaldehyde is produced as alcohols burn

shortDefinitions: any organic compound whose molecule contains one or more hydroxyl groups attached to carbon atom
